These Italian democrats believe we Americans are naive about both
communism and fascism. They sayf perhaps with some Justification, that
they know both better than we do. They say they know communism better
because they have had to live with the threat of it in these postwar
year© in which better than one out of every three Italians has voted for
the Reds ana their Left Socialist allies. Therefore, they do not
appreciate advice from us on how to cope with this problem.
And they fear that the United States, in its anxiety over the com¬
munist problem, is headed down the road to some kind of totalitarianism,
which they generally call Fascism. They cite what they regard as ultra-
nationalism, exemplified by the restrictive provisions of the NeCarran
act; the congressional investigations; the attacks on educators and the
public schools. And they say: W© know these things well; they are like
the things that came to Italy 30 years ago.
Another thing that bothers Italian democrats more than any other
about American foreign policy is what they regard as our zeal to rearm
Germany. The Italian government repeatedly has taken a strong stand for
the European Defense Community treaty. That's the treaty that would
rearm western Germans as part of an integrated supra-national, European
army. But Italians know that the pressure for rearming the Germans in
the first place came from the United States. And they fear the longrange
effects of such a pft policy.
